And file sharing.
File-sharing.

The discussions take place in specific image forums, whether they'd be 4Chan or others.
Image forum?
What is an image forum?
An image forum is basically a place where you post a picture of something and then you write some kind of blurb about it.
The kind of thing that people really don't understand about 4Chan, specifically, is it's not really this hotbed for political talks or anything.
Actually, it's largely pornography and gore pictures and...

manga, all of those.
Japanese manga, yeah.

I often wonder why the government doesn't try and amend the Copyright Act to allow copyright protection for government documents and at the same time allowing public use license that would only protect these documents if they were, say, classified, otherwise they would be free to be used without any reservation.
Well, you'd think being stamped ""secret"" would be protection enough.
Would copyright protection be more efficient, do you think, Jim Lewis?

The problem that they have is that the WikiLeaks folks - and this is what I think the question gets to - the WikiLeaks folks, you know, the most you could say about them, maybe we'll get them under the secrets - the Espionage Act of 1917, maybe we'll get them under receiving stolen goods or something, but there isn't a good legal hook to get them.
And if you could move these documents into the IP protections, maybe you could have a better hook for going after them.
But just a hard process.
And so, you know, WikiLeaks exploited a vulnerability that has existed in the system, and we'll probably find some way to fix it.
IP might just be too hard because of all the economic issues around it.
Well, a lot of people are saying, yes, WikiLeaks has been the purveyor of all of this, but the State Department is responsible for lax security and making these things too easy to get.
Yeah, that was the big problem, is a single private should not have been able to download 250,000 cables onto a Lady Gaga CD.
And there is technology that would prevent that.
This isn't a new problem.
Companies have faced it.
And we didn't have the safeguards in place.
After 9/11, there was a big emphasis on information sharing and letting people look at all the documents and databases so that we wouldn't miss the needle in the haystack, to use the favorite cliche.

And the problem was as we built the system for information sharing, more information sharing, but we didn't change the safeguards around it from the old safeguards we had in place in paper days, including classification.
So that's where - there was a hole.
James, thanks very much.
Thank you.

Yeah.
Going back to the Sarah Palin attack, I was just wondering, we are seeing some more sophisticated attacks on specific people.
Is there any kind of information or any kind of, I don't know, trend towards maybe some of these more advanced attacks going towards political movements or anything like that.
Yeah, not just Sarah Palin but the Swedish prosecutor who's involved in the allegations against Julian Assange.
Certainly, the ability to do this is out there.

And one of the things that we've seen, maybe in the last year, is that the higher-end cyber criminals will use things like Facebook, get personal identification, personal information on you, and then do targeted attacks.
In the past, it's been mainly on wealthy individuals, high-ranking business executives, scientists.
And you wouldn't be surprised to see it start to shift to some of these political opponents.
But one of the vulnerabilities of putting up your pet's name on Facebook - and I'm not saying anybody does that - is if you then use it for your password, they're in.
And actually, we have seen stuff like that happen.
So it's an interesting point as to whether the things that we now see being used in cybercrime at the high end will move over into politics.
Tim, thanks very much.
Thanks.
